ProjectOverview.Title: LocalNetChat
ProjectOverview.Description: A lightweight desktop chat application that enables users on the same local network to exchange text messages, display user status, and share files. The application uses peer‑to‑peer communication over TCP/UDP and is designed for office, educational, or home environments where internet connectivity is limited or unavailable.
ProjectOverview.Scope: Desktop clients (Windows, macOS, Linux) with optional mobile preview. No external server; all data is transmitted directly between clients.

Stakeholders.description: Employees, students, or home users who need quick local communication.
Manages network policies and ensures compliance.

Assumptions: All clients are on the same subnet or can discover each other via multicast/broadcast.
Users have permission to open required ports on local firewall.
File sizes are limited to 100 MB per transfer to keep bandwidth usage reasonable.
Constraints: Cross‑platform compatibility with Java 17 (Swing) or Electron/Node.js.
Security: encryption optional but recommended; no user authentication beyond local login.

UserStories.title: Discover and connect to peers
UserStories.description: As a user, I want the app to automatically discover other users on the local network so that I can start chatting without manual IP entry.
acceptanceCriteria: The app broadcasts a presence packet every 5 seconds.
A list of online users appears in the UI within 2 seconds of startup.
Clicking a user initiates a chat window.

UserStories.title: Send and receive text messages
UserStories.description: As a user, I want to send text messages that appear instantly in the chat window.
acceptanceCriteria: Messages are displayed with timestamp and sender name.
Message history persists for the current session only.

UserStories.title: View user status
UserStories.description: As a user, I want to see whether other users are online, away, or offline.
acceptanceCriteria: Status updates are broadcast every 10 seconds.
Status changes are reflected in the user list in real time.

UserStories.title: Share files with peers
UserStories.description: As a user, I want to send a file to another user and receive a prompt to accept or decline.
acceptanceCriteria: File transfer initiates after user confirms.
Accepted files are saved to a user‑defined folder.

UserStories.title: Handle network interruptions
UserStories.description: As a user, I want the app to notify me if a peer disconnects or the network is lost.
acceptanceCriteria: Disconnection causes a status change to offline.
Attempting to send a message to a disconnected user shows an error.

FunctionalRequirements.details: Implement UDP multicast/broadcast to announce presence and listen for peers. Each client sends a JSON packet containing user ID, name, status, and listening port.
When a user selects a peer, the client initiates a TCP connection on the peer's advertised port. The connection is used for text and file transfer.
Define a lightweight JSON schema for messages: {type:'msg', from:'id', to:'id', timestamp:'ISO8601', content:'text'}.
Send periodic status updates: {type:'status', id:'id', status:'online|away|offline'}.
Use a separate TCP stream with header: {type:'file', from:'id', to:'id', filename:'string', size:bytes}. Followed by raw file bytes. Support pause/resume via checksum verification.
Main window shows user list with status icons, chat area, and file transfer panel. Context menu to start chat or send file.
Allow user to set display name, status message, and default download folder.
Provide a toggle to enable TLS for all peer connections.

NonFunctionalRequirements.details: Message latency < 200 ms on a typical LAN. File transfer throughput ≥ 5 Mbps.
Support up to 50 concurrent peers without noticeable UI lag.
Automatic reconnection attempts every 5 seconds if connection drops.
All primary actions (send message, send file, change status) must be accessible via keyboard shortcuts.
Data in transit is encrypted if TLS is enabled. No sensitive data is stored on disk.
Runs on Windows 10+, macOS 10.13+, and Ubuntu 18.04+.

BusinessRules.description: All users must be on the same subnet or have multicast support for discovery to work.
File size limit per transfer is 100 MB; larger files must be split or rejected.
If a user sets status to 'away', they cannot receive file transfer requests.
The application must log all connection attempts for audit purposes but must not log message contents.

SuccessCriteria.description: All user stories are implemented and pass automated unit and integration tests.
The app is stable on all targeted platforms with no memory leaks (> 512 MB RAM usage).
User acceptance test score ≥ 90 % on usability survey.
Network traffic analysis shows minimal overhead: discovery packets < 1 kB, message packets < 512 B.
